gremlins

Class Mobile

  • java.lang.Object
    • gremlins.Entity
      • gremlins.Mobile
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Gremlin, Projectile, Wizard

    public abstract class Mobile
extends Entity
    Mobile class: An abstract entity that has the ability to actively change their location

        public abstract int draw(App app)

        Returns:
        an integer that determines how that object may interact with other objects. A 0 is typically returned, but in the case of a mobile like the wizard, the draw method returns the direction it was last drawn in.

      • upCollision

        public int upCollision(App app)
        First of 4 directional collision methods. Up collision evaluates whether when the wizard is moving up, it collides with something The mobile object's side availability hashmap is modified in this method that carries on to determine which directions it can/cannot move in
        Parameters:
        app - used to access the App class which contains the ArrayLists of mobile and immobile objects that must be compared to No major offset is required, as the starting test point is the top left hand corner
        Returns:
        an integer that denotes whether a collision has occurred (1 is a collision has occurred, and 0 is no collision)

      • rightCollision

        public int rightCollision(App app)
        Second of 4 directional collision methods. Right collision evaluates whether when the wizard is moving right, it collides with something The mobile object's side availability hashmap is modified in this method that carries on to determine which directions it can/cannot move in A major 20 pixel offset is required as the starting test point is the top left hand corner. To change this, The sprite's width (20 pixels) is added to offset this colliision.
        Parameters:
        app - used to access the App class which contains the ArrayLists of mobile and immobile objects that must be compared to
        Returns:
        an integer that denotes whether a collision has occurred (1 is a collision has occurred, and 0 is no collision)

      • leftCollision

        public int leftCollision(App app)
        Third of 4 directional collision methods. Down collision evaluates whether when the wizard is moving down, it collides with something The mobile object's side availability hashmap is modified in this method that carries on to determine which directions it can/cannot move in A major offset of 20 pixels down is required as the test point is the top left hand corner. To implement this, the Sprite's height (20 pixels) is added to offset this coliison
        Parameters:
        app - used to access the App class which contains the ArrayLists of mobile and immobile objects that must be compared to
        Returns:
        an integer that denotes whether a collision has occurred (1 is a collision has occurred, and 0 is no collision)

      • downCollision

        public int downCollision(App app)
        Last of 4 directional collision methods. Left collision evaluates whether when the wizard is moving left, it collides with something The mobile object's side availability hashmap is modified in this method that carries on to determine which directions it can/cannot move in No major offset is required, as the test point is always top left. As it is on the left, no consistent offset is required.
        Parameters:
        app - used to access the App class which contains the ArrayLists of mobile and immobile objects that must be compared to
        Returns:
        an integer that denotes whether a collision has occurred (1 is a collision has occurred, and 0 is no collision)

      • collision

        public int collision(App app)
        This collision method is consistently called, but the only collisions for the mobile that are assessed are in the direction it is travelling. Each mobile entity can only at most hit one thing that changes its 'state' significantly. Thus, only the collision algorithm in the direction the mobile is moving is assessed. This functions, as if another mobile hits the current mobile from behind, the current mobile may not detect it, but the one that hit the current mobile will have. Thus, computational power and memory is saved for other tasks.
        Parameters:
        app - used to access the ArrayLists of mobile and immobile objects the 'current mobile' must be compared to
        Returns:
        an integer that denotes whether a collision has occurrd (1 is collision has occured, 0 is no collision)

      • collides

        public boolean collides(int xCoord,
                        int yCoord,
                        App app)
        The collides method truely assesses whether two objects are colliding (i.e. if two test points are within the range of the width/height of the entity it is testing against). There are two major classes of collisions: Block (immobile) collisions, and Mobile collisions, assessed using the two for loops The objects the current entity has collided with are saved in the two mobile attributes called collisionBlock and collisionEntity, that are heavily used by both child and parent classes.
        Parameters:
        xCoord - the x coordinate of this current mobile's test point
        yCoord - the y coordinate of this current mobile's test point
        app - used to access the ArrayLists of mobile and immobile objects
        Returns:
        a boolean, true or false depending on whether a mobile or immobile has been contacted
